text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the official Vietnamese press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet has agreed that construction of the country's first oil refinery should begin this year, without any foreign partners and with all finances to be raised by the government.
-- The U.S. Trade and Development Agency's director, Joseph Grandmaison, begins a five-day visit to Vietnam on Monday.

-- Deputy Foreign Minister Vu Khoan said Vietnam wants stability in Cambodia so that bilateral ties, especially those concerning trade and economic issues, can be maintained and developed on the basis of mutual benefits.
-- A new regulation released by the State Bank of Vietnam permits banks to trade in short-term loans.
-- Communist Party Secretary General Do Muoi on Monday begins an official visit to China at the invitation of Chinese Party leader and President Jiang Zemin.
-- Vietnam reported a year-on-year GDP growth rate of 9.1 percent in the first half of 1997.
-- The Hanoi People's Council said bad management was the main reason for shortcomings in the socio-economic development of the city during the first six months of this year.
-- Deputy Prime Minister Phan Van Khai has called for speeding up production to boost budget revenue in the second half of 1997.
